Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back simply and well-modelled with clypeus, some feathering for legs in front, prothorax indicated by single lines and double lines for elytra; humeral callosities indicated by triangular nicks and small triangles marking winglets on either side behind the prothorax line; at side, legs well-modelled with deeply undercut triangle; underside decorated with representation of a lion walking to right with head looking forward and tail held high, sun-disc above its back and an unidentified element (hieroglyphic sign?) in front of animal; motif stamped rather than incised, encircled by groove near edge; longitudinally pierced; pale greenish cream glaze overall; core not visible.
Curator's comments: The faience object was analysed by proton induced X-ray emission spectrometry (PIXE) under a 3 MeV energy proton beam for characterisation of the elemental chemical composition (major, minor and trace elements), in March 2014, by the Centre de Recherche et de Restauration des Musées de France (C2RMF). Scarabs with a lion motif depicted on the base belong to a standard group produced at the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Petrie illustrated a number of different versions (Petrie 1886, pl. 37, 34-45). This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93, 95-96, type XXVIII A, subtype A6-39, see especially A6 for this piece). Gorton, A. F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W. M. F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, 'Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site', in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming, Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 34) (other attestations of the same motif)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (Type XXVIII A6)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.002) (phase 3)
